a.g: O you who have believed, do not put [yourselves] before Allah and His Messenger but fear Allah. Indeed, Allah is Hearing and Knowing.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
ترفع الأصوات عليه فيصبر حديث ترفع الأصوات عنده فيصبر أخرجه البخاري من حديث عبد الله بن الزبير قدم ركب من بني تميم على النبي صلى الله عليه وسلم فقال أبو بكر أمر القعقاع بن معبد وقال عمر بل أمر الأقرع بن حابس فقال أبو بكر ما أردت إلا خلافي وقال عمر ما أردت خلافك فتماريا حتى ارتفعت أصواتهما فنزلت يا أيها الذين آمنوا لا تقدموا بين يدي الله ورسوله
Indeed, O you who have believed, do not raise your voices above the voice of the Prophet, and do not be loud to him in speech like the loudness of some of you to others, lest your deeds become worthless while you perceive not. Indeed, those who lower their voices in the presence of the Messenger of God [rasul Allah] – those are the ones whose hearts [qulub] God has tested for reverence [taqwa]. For them is forgiveness and a great reward. Indeed, those who call you from behind the private chambers – most of them do not reason. And if they had patience [sabr] until you come out to them, it would be better for them. And God is Forgiving, Merciful. O you who have believed, if a wicked person comes to you with information, investigate, lest you harm a people in ignorance and become, over what you have done, regretful. And know that among you is the Messenger of God [rasul Allah]. If he were to obey you in much of the matter, you would be in difficulty, but God has endeared faith [iman] to you and made it pleasing in your hearts [qulub], and He has made disbelief, defiance, and disobedience hateful to you. Those are the rightly guided. [It is] a bounty from God and favor. And God is Knowing, Wise.

a.g: O you who have believed, do not raise your voices above the voice of the Prophet or be loud to him in speech like the loudness of some of you to others, lest your deeds become worthless while you perceive not.
Indeed, those who lower their voices before the Messenger of Allah - they are the ones whose hearts Allah has tested for righteousness. For them is forgiveness and great reward.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
اعلم أن ما ذكرناه إن تأملته بعين الاعتبار انفتحت بصيرتك وانكشف لك علل القلوب وأمراضها وأدويتها بنور العلم واليقين، فإن عجزت عن ذلك فلا ينبغي أن يفوتك التصديق والإيمان على سبيل التلقي والتقليد لمن يستحق التقليد، فإن للإيمان درجة كما أن للعلم درجة، والعلم يحصل بعد الإيمان وهو وراءه قال الله تعالى "يرفع الله الذين آمنوا منكم والذين أوتوا العلم درجات" فمن صدق بأن مخالفة الشهوات هي الطريق إلى الله عز وجل ولم يطلع على سببه وسره فهو من الذين آمنوا، وإذا اطلع على ما ذكرناه من أعوان الشهوات فهو من الذين أوتوا العلم وكلا وعد الله الحسنى. والذي يقتضي الإيمان بهذا الأمر في القرآن والسنة وأقاويل العلماء أكثر من أن يحصر. قال الله تعالى "ونهى النفس عن الهوى فإن الجنة هي المأوى" وقال تعالى "أولئك الذين امتحن الله قلوبهم للتقوى" قيل نزع منها محبة الشهوات.
Know that what We have mentioned, if you contemplate it with the eye of consideration [i'tibar], your insight [basira] will open and the ailments [amrad] of the hearts [qulub], their sicknesses and their cures, will be unveiled to you by the light [nur] of knowledge ['ilm] and certainty [yaqin]. If you are incapable of that, then you should not miss out on belief [tasdiq] and faith [iman] by way of reception [talqin] and following authority [taqlid] of one who deserves to be followed, for faith [iman] has a degree, just as knowledge ['ilm] has a degree, and knowledge is attained after faith and is beyond it. Allah the Exalted said: "Allah will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge, by degrees." So whoever believes with certainty [sadaqa] that opposing the appetites [shahawat] is the path to Allah, Mighty and Majestic is He, yet does not become aware of its cause and its secret, he is among those who have believed. And if he becomes aware of what We have mentioned concerning the allies [a'wan] of the appetites, then he is among those who were given knowledge, and to both Allah has promised the best reward. That which necessitates faith in this matter from the Qur'an, the Sunnah, and the statements of the scholars is too numerous to be enumerated. Allah the Exalted said: "And he who restrains the soul [nafs] from caprice [hawa], then indeed Paradise is the refuge." And He the Exalted said: "Those are the ones whose hearts Allah has tested for God-consciousness [taqwa]." It is said: He extracted from them the love of appetites.

a.g: Indeed, those who call you, [O Muhammad], from behind the chambers - most of them do not use reason.
And if they had been patient until you [could] come out to them, it would have been better for them. But Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
O you who have believed, if there comes to you a disobedient one with information, investigate, lest you harm a people out of ignorance and become, over what you have done, regretful.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقد قال الله تعالى يا أيها الذين آمنوا إن جاءكم فاسق بنبأ فتبينوا ذكر ذلك تحذيرا وتنبيها للاحتراز منه في المستقبل
Indeed, O you who have believed, if a wicked person [fāsiq] comes to you with a report, then verify it. This is mentioned as a warning and an alert to guard against it in the future.

w.e: orang-orang yang mengikuti jalan yang lurus

a.g: And know that among you is the Messenger of Allah. If he were to obey you in much of the matter, you would be in difficulty, but Allah has endeared to you the faith and has made it pleasing in your hearts and has made hateful to you disbelief, defiance and disobedience. Those are the [rightly] guided.
[It is] as bounty from Allah and favor. And Allah is Knowing and Wise.

And if two factions among the believers should fight, then make settlement between the two. But if one of them oppresses the other, then fight against the one that oppresses until it returns to the ordinance of Allah. And if it returns, then make settlement between them in justice and act justly. Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقال تعالى وإن طائفتان من المؤمنين اقتتلوا فأصلحوا بينهما الآية والاصلاح نهي عن البغي وإعادة إلى الطاعة فإن لم يفعل فقد أمر الله تعالى بقتاله فقال فقاتلوا التي تبغي حتى تفيء إلى أمر الله وذلك هو النهي عن المنكر
Indeed, if two factions [ta'ifatān] from among the believers fight, then make peace between them... And the reconciliation [al-islāh] is a prohibition against transgression [al-baghy] and a restoration to obedience [al-tā'ah]. If they do not do so, then Allah the Exalted has commanded to fight them, so He said: "Then fight the one that transgresses until it returns to the command of Allah." And that is the prohibition of the reprehensible [al-munkar].

a.g: The believers are but brothers, so make settlement between your brothers. And fear Allah that you may receive mercy.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
والعادلون إلى طلب الرياسة بالعلوم خارجون عن موجب قوله تعالى: (إنما المؤمنون إخوة ( (الحجرات: 10) وداخلون في مقتضى قوله تعالى: (الأخلاء يومئذ بعضهم لبعض عدو إلا المتقين( (الزخرف: 67).
Indeed, those who turn to seeking leadership [ri'asa] through knowledge [ulum] are departing from the imperative of His saying, the Most High: "Indeed, the believers are brothers [ikhwa]" (Al-Hujurat: 10), and are entering into the consequence of His saying, the Most High: "Close friends [akhilla'] on that Day will be enemies to one another except for the righteous [muttaqin]" (Az-Zukhruf: 67).

a.g: O you who have believed, let not a people ridicule [another] people; perhaps they may be better than them; nor let women ridicule [other] women; perhaps they may be better than them. And do not insult one another and do not call each other by [offensive] nicknames. Wretched is the name of disobedience after [one's] faith. And whoever does not repent - then it is those who are the wrongdoers.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
الآفة الحادية عشر السخرية والاستهزاء وهذا محرم مهما كان مؤذياً كما قال تعالى "يا أيها الذين آمنوا لا يسخر قوم من قوم عسى أن يكونوا خيراً منهم ولا نساء من نساء عسى أن يكن خيراً منهن" ومعنى السخرية الاستهانة والتحقير والتنبيه على العيوب والنقائص على وجه يضحك منه: وقد يكون ذلك بالمحاكاة في الفعل والقول، وقد يكون بالإشارة والإيماء، وإذا كان بحضرة المستهزأ به لم يسم ذلك غيبة وفيه معنى الغيبة. وعليه قوله تعالى "عسى أن يكونوا خيراً منهم" أي لا تستحقره استصغاراً فلعله خير منك. وهذا إنما يحرم في حق من يتأذى به، فأما من جعل نفسه مسخرة وربما فرح من أن يسخر به كانت السخرية في حقه من جملة المزاح -وقد سبق ما يذم منه وما يمدح- وإنما المحرم استصغار يتأذى به المستهزأ به لما فيه من التحقير والتهاون. وذلك تارة بأن يضحك على كلامه إذا تخبط فيه ولم ينتظم، أو على أفعاله إذا كانت مشوشة كالضحك على خطه وعلى صنعته، أو على صورته وخلقته إذا كان قصيراً أو ناقصاً لعيب من العيوب. فالضحك من جميع ذلك داخل في السخرية المنهي عنها.
Indeed, the eleventh affliction is mockery [sukhriyah] and derision [istihza']. And this is forbidden, however much it may cause harm, just as the Almighty has said: "O you who have believed, let not a people ridicule [another] people; perhaps they may be better than them; nor let women ridicule [other] women; perhaps they may be better than them." And the meaning of mockery [sukhriyah] is belittlement [istihana] and contempt [tahqir], and pointing out faults and deficiencies in a manner that provokes laughter from it. And that may be through imitation in action and speech, and it may be through gesture and indication. And if it is in the presence of the one being ridiculed, it is not called backbiting [ghibah], yet it contains the meaning of backbiting. And upon this is His saying, the Almighty: "perhaps they may be better than them" — meaning, do not hold him in contempt, belittling him, for perhaps he is better than you. And this is only forbidden regarding one who is harmed by it. As for one who makes himself an object of mockery, and perhaps even delights in being mocked, then mockery regarding him is from the category of jesting — and what is blameworthy and what is praiseworthy in it has preceded. The forbidden is only the belittlement that harms the one being ridiculed, due to what it contains of contempt and disregard. And that is sometimes by laughing at his speech if he falters in it and it is not coherent, or at his actions if they are confused, such as laughing at his handwriting and at his handiwork, or at his appearance and his form if he is short or deficient due to some defect. So laughing at all of that enters into the mockery [sukhriyah] that is prohibited.

a.g: O you who have believed, avoid much [negative] assumption. Indeed, some assumption is sin. And do not spy or backbite each other. Would one of you like to eat the flesh of his brother when dead? You would detest it. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is Accepting of repentance and Merciful.

Indeed, from its doors is having bad suspicion [su' al-zann] towards the Muslims. Allah the Exalted says: "O you who have believed, avoid much [negative] assumption. Indeed, some assumption is sin." For whoever judges evil upon another based on suspicion [zann], Satan incites him to either extend his tongue in backbiting [ghiba] about him, thus perishing, or to fall short in fulfilling his due rights, or to be negligent in honoring him, and to look at him with an eye of contempt, and to see himself as better than him. All of that is from the destructive matters. And for that reason, the Sacred Law [al-shar'] prohibited exposing oneself to suspicions [al-tuhum].

a.g: O mankind, indeed We have created you from male and female and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another. Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Acquainted.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وسئل ابن عباس: ما الكرم؟ فقال: هو ما بين الله في كتابه العزيز "إن أكرمكم عند الله أتقاكم" قيل فما الحسب؟ قال: أحسنكم خلقاً أفضلكم حسباً.
Indeed, the fourth [type] is pride in noble lineage [nasab], like the pride of the Hashimites, to the point that some of them imagine they will be saved by the nobility of their lineage [nasab] and the salvation of their forefathers, and that they are forgiven. And some of them fancy that all creation are their clients and slaves. Its remedy is that he should know: however much he opposes his forefathers in their actions [af'al] and their character traits [akhlaq], and yet imagines he is attached to them, then he is ignorant. And if he follows his forefathers, then what was from their character traits [akhlaq] was not pride ['ujb], but rather fear [khawf] and contempt for the self [nafs] and magnifying the creation [khalq] and censuring the self [nafs]. And they were ennobled by obedience [ta'a] and knowledge ['ilm] and praiseworthy qualities [khisal hamida], not by lineage [nasab]. So let him seek nobility with that by which they were ennobled. And those who did not believe in Allah and the Last Day have equaled them in lineage [nasab] and shared with them in the tribes, and they were, with Allah, worse than dogs and more base than swine. And for that reason, the Most High said: "O mankind, indeed We have created you from a male and a female" — meaning there is no distinction in your lineages [ansab] due to your gathering in a single origin. Then He mentioned the benefit of lineage [nasab], saying: "and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another." Then He made clear that nobility [sharaf] is through God-consciousness [taqwa], not through lineage [nasab], saying: "Indeed, the most noble of you with Allah is the most God-conscious of you."

a.g: The bedouins say, "We have believed." Say, "You have not [yet] believed; but say [instead], 'We have submitted,' for faith has not yet entered your hearts. And if you obey Allah and His Messenger, He will not deprive you from your deeds of anything. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وكل عبد مصطفى. [الفصل الرابع من قواعد العقائد] في الإيمان والإسلام وما بينهما من الاتصال وما يتطرق إليه من الزيادة والنقصان ووجه استثناء السلف فيه وفيه ثلاث مسائل. [مسألة] اختلفوا في أن الإسلام هو الإيمان أو غيره وإن كان غيره فهل هو منفصل عنه يوجد دونه أو مرتبط به يلازمه فقيل إنهما شيء واحد وقيل إنهما شيئان لا يتواصلان وقيل إنهما شيئان ولكن يرتبط أحدهما بالآخر وقد أورد أبو طالب المكي في هذا كلاما شديد الاضطراب كثير التطويل فلنهجم الآن على التصريح بالحق من غير تعريج على نقل ما لا تحصيل له فنقول في هذا ثلاثة مباحث بحث عن موجب اللفظين في اللغة وبحث عن المراد بهما في إطلاق الشرع وبحث عن حكمهما في الدنيا والآخرة والبحث الأول لغوي والثاني تفسيري والثالث فقهي شرعي: البحث الأول: في موجب اللغة والحق فيه أن الإيمان عبارة عن التصديق قال الله تعالى: ﴿ وما أنت بمؤمن لنا ﴾ {} أي بمصدق والإسلام عبارة عن التسليم والاستسلام بالإذعان والانقياد وترك التمرد والإباء والعناد وللتصديق محل خاص وهو القلب واللسان ترجمان وأما التسليم فإنه عام في القلب واللسان والجوارح فإن كل تصديق بالقلب فهو تسليم وترك الإباء والجحود وكذلك الاعتراف باللسان وكذلك الطاعة والانقياد بالجوارح فموجب اللغة أن الإسلام أعم والإيمان أخص فكان الإيمان عبارة عن أشرف أجزاء الإسلام فإذن كل تصديق تسليم وليس كل تسليم تصديقا. البحث الثاني: عن إطلاق الشرع والحق فيه أن الشرع قد ورد باستعمالهما على سبيل الترادف والتوارد وورد على سبيل الاختلاف وورد على سبيل التداخل. أما الترادف ففي قوله تعالى: ﴿ فأخرجنا من كان فيها من المؤمنين. فما وجدنا فيها غير بيت من المسلمين ﴾ {} ولم يكن بالاتفاق إلا بيت واحد وقال تعالى: ﴿ يا قوم إن كنتم آمنتم بالله فعليه توكلوا إن كنتم مسلمين ﴾ {} وأما الاختلاف فقوله تعالى: ﴿ قالت الأعراب آمنا قل لم تؤمنوا ولكن قولوا أسلمنا ﴾ {} ومعناه استسلمنا في الظاهر فأراد بالإيمان ههنا التصديق بالقلب فقط وبالإسلام الاستسلام ظاهرا باللسان والجوارح، وفي حديث جبرائيل عليه السلام لما سأله عن الإيمان فقال: (أن تؤمن بالله وملائكته وكتبه ورسله واليوم الآخر وبالبعث بعد الموت وبالحساب وبالقدر خيره وشره فقال فما الإسلام فأجاب بذكر الخصال الخمس[47]) فعبر بالإسلام عن تسليم الظاهر بالقول والعمل وفي الحديث عن سعد أنه ﭬ (أعطى رجلا عطاء ولم يعط الآخر فقال له سعد: يا رسول الله تركت فلانا لم تعطه وهو مؤمن فقال ﭬ: أو مسلم فأعاد عليه فأعاد رسول الله ﭬ[48]) وأما التداخل فما روي أيضا أنه سئل (فقيل أي الأعمال أفضل فقال ﭬ: الإسلام فقال أي الإسلام أفضل؟ فقال ﭬ: الإيمان[49]) وهذا دليل على الاختلاف وعلى التداخل وهو أوفق الاستعمالات في اللغة لأن الإيمان عمل من الأعمال وهو أفضلها والإسلام هو تسليم إما بالقلب وإما باللسان وإما بالجوارح وأفضلها الذي بالقلب وهو التصديق الذي يسمى إيمانا والاستعمال لهما على سبيل الاختلاف وعلى سبيل التداخل وعلى سبيل الترادف كله غير خارج عن طريق التجوز في اللغة أما الاختلاف فهو أن يجعل الإيمان عبارة عن التصديق بالقلب فقط وهو موافق للغة والإسلام عبارة عن التسليم ظاهرا وهو أيضا موافق للغة فإن التسليم ببعض محال التسليم ينطلق عليه اسم التسليم فليس من شرط حصول الاسم عموم المعنى لكل محل يمكن أن يوجد المعنى فيه فإن من لمس غيره ببعض بدنه يسمى لامسا وإن لم يستغرق جميع بدنه فإطلاق اسم الإسلام على التسليم الظاهر عند عدم تسليم الباطن مطابق للسان وعلى هذا الوجه جرى قوله تعالى: ﴿ قالت الأعراب آمنا قل لم تؤمنوا ولكن قولوا أسلمنا ﴾ {} وقوله ﭬ في حديث سعد (أو مسلم) لأنه فضل أحدهما على الآخر ويريد بالاختلاف تفاضل المسميين وأما التداخل فموافق أيضا للغة في خصوص الإيمان وهو أن يجعل الإسلام عبارة عن التسليم بالقلب والقول والعمل جميعا والإيمان عبارة عن بعض ما دخل في الإسلام وهو التصديق بالقلب
Indeed, every chosen servant. [The Fourth Chapter of the Foundations of Belief] concerning faith [iman] and submission [islam] and the connection between them, and what may affect them of increase and decrease, and the manner of the predecessors' exception in it. And in it are three issues. [Issue] They differed regarding whether submission [islam] is faith [iman] or other than it. And if it is other, then is it separate from it, existing without it, or linked to it, inseparable from it? So it was said they are one thing, and it was said they are two things not connected, and it was said they are two things but one is linked to the other. Abu Talib al-Makki has presented on this speech of severe confusion and much length. So let us now rush to declare the truth directly, without digressing to relay what has no benefit. We say in this three investigations: an investigation into what the two terms necessitate in language, an investigation into what is intended by them in the usage of the Sacred Law, and an investigation into their ruling in this world [dunya] and the Hereafter. The first investigation is linguistic, the second is interpretive, and the third is jurisprudential and legal. **The First Investigation:** Concerning what language necessitates. The truth in it is that faith [iman] is an expression for affirmation [tasdiq]. Allah, the Exalted, says: {And you are not a believer for us} meaning an affirmer. And submission [islam] is an expression for surrender [taslim] and yielding [istislam] through acquiescence and compliance, and abandoning rebellion, refusal, and obstinacy. Affirmation [tasdiq] has a specific locus, which is the heart [qalb], and the tongue is its interpreter. As for surrender [taslim], it is general to the heart [qalb], the tongue, and the limbs. For every affirmation [tasdiq] by the heart [qalb] is a surrender [taslim] and an abandonment of refusal and denial. Likewise, the acknowledgment by the tongue. Likewise, obedience and compliance by the limbs. So what language necessitates is that submission [islam] is more general and faith [iman] is more specific. Thus, faith [iman] is an expression for the most noble part of submission [islam]. Therefore, every affirmation [tasdiq] is a surrender [taslim], but not every surrender [taslim] is an affirmation [tasdiq]. **The Second Investigation:** Concerning the usage of the Sacred Law. The truth in it is that the Sacred Law has come using them interchangeably and concurrently, and has come with a distinction, and has come with overlap. As for interchangeability, it is in His saying, the Exalted: {So We brought out whoever was in it of the believers. And We found not within it except one house of those who had submitted [muslimin].} And there was, by agreement, only one house. And He, the Exalted, said: {O my people, if you have believed in Allah, then upon Him rely, if you should be submitters [muslimin].} As for distinction, it is His saying, the Exalted: {The Bedouins say, "We have believed." Say, "You have not believed; but say, 'We have submitted [aslamna],'"} and its meaning is: we have surrendered outwardly. So He intended by faith [iman] here affirmation [tasdiq] by the heart [qalb] only, and by submission [islam] outward surrender [istislam] by the tongue and limbs. And in the hadith of Gabriel, peace be upon him, when he asked him about faith [iman], he said: "That you believe in Allah and His angels and His books and His messengers and the Last Day, and in resurrection after death, and in the Reckoning, and in the Decree, its good and its evil." Then he said: "So what is submission [islam]?" So he answered by mentioning the five pillars. Thus, he expressed submission [islam] as the surrender [taslim] of the outward through speech and action. And in the hadith concerning Sa'd, that he (gave a gift to a man and did not give to another. So Sa'd said to him: "O Messenger of Allah, you left so-and-so, you did not give him, and he is a believer [mu'min]." So he said: "Or a submitter [muslim]." He repeated it to him, and the Messenger of Allah repeated it.) As for overlap, it is what was also narrated that he was asked: "Which deeds are best?" He said: "Submission [islam]." He said: "Which submission [islam] is best?" He said: "Faith [iman]." This is evidence for distinction and for overlap. And it is the most suitable of the usages in language, because faith [iman] is an action from among the actions, and it is the best of them. And submission [islam] is surrender [taslim], whether by the heart [qalb], or by the tongue, or by the limbs. And the best of it is that which is by the heart [qalb], which is affirmation [tasdiq] that is called faith [iman]. And the usage of them for distinction, and for overlap, and for interchangeability, all of it is not outside the path of figurative usage in language. As for distinction, it is to make faith [iman] an expression for affirmation [tasdiq] by the heart [qalb] only, which agrees with language. And submission [islam] an expression for outward surrender [taslim], which also agrees with language. For surrender [taslim] with some of the places of surrender [taslim] is applied to it the name of surrender [taslim]. It is not a condition for the realization of the name that the meaning be general to every place the meaning can exist within. For whoever touches another with some part of his body is called a toucher, even if it does not encompass all of his body. So applying the name submission [islam] to outward surrender [taslim] when there is no surrender of the inward conforms to language. And upon this meaning proceeded His saying, the Exalted: {The Bedouins say, "We have believed." Say, "You have not believed; but say, 'We have submitted [aslamna],'"} and His saying in the hadith of Sa'd: "Or a submitter [muslim]" because he preferred one of them over the other, intending by distinction the superiority of the two named things. As for overlap, it also agrees with language in the specificity of faith [iman], which is to make submission [islam] an expression for surrender [taslim] by the heart [qalb], speech, and action all together, and faith [iman] an expression for some of what entered into submission [islam], which is affirmation [tasdiq] by the heart [qalb].

a.g: The believers are only the ones who have believed in Allah and His Messenger and then doubt not but strive with their properties and their lives in the cause of Allah. It is those who are the truthful.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقد أشار القرآن إلى هذه الأخلاق في أوصاف المؤمنين فقال تعالى "إنما المؤمنون الذين آمنوا بالله ورسوله ثم لم يرتابوا وجاهدوا بأموالهم وأنفسهم في سبيل الله أولئك هم الصادقون" فالإيمان بالله وبرسوله من غير ارتياب هو قوة اليقين وهو ثمرة العقل. ومنتهى الحكمة والمجاهدة بالمال هو السخاء الذي يرجع إلى ضبط قوة الشهوة. والمجاهدة بالنفس هي الشجاعة التي ترجع إلى استعمال قوة الغضب على شرط العقل وحد الاعتدال.
Indeed, the Qur'an has alluded to these character traits in the descriptions of the believers, and He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, the believers are only those who have believed in Allah and His Messenger, then have not doubted, and have striven with their wealth and their selves in the way of Allah. It is those who are the truthful [al-sadiqun]." So, belief [iman] in Allah and His Messenger without doubt is the strength of certainty [yaqin], and it is the fruit of the intellect [aql]. And the ultimate striving with wealth is generosity [sakha'], which refers back to controlling the power of appetite [shahwa]. And striving with the self [nafs] is courage [shuja'a], which refers back to employing the power of anger [ghadab] according to the stipulation of the intellect [aql] and the limit of moderation [i'tidal].

a.g: Say, "Would you acquaint Allah with your religion while Allah knows whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth, and Allah is Knowing of all things?"
